repnme.cdata!:
Egypt - Second Pumping Stations
            Rehabilitation and National Drainage Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Mixed ratings are conveyed through the
            Implementation Completion Report (ICR), ICR review, and
            those of this audit process, in regards to the Second
            Pumping Stations Rehabilitation Project, which ranks project
            outcomes as moderately unsatisfactory in contrast to
            satisfactory ratings by the ICR; unlikely sustainability as
            opposed to likely by the ICR, and uncertain by the ICR
            review; negligible institutional development impacts in
            contrast to substantial by both the ICR and ICR review; and,
            both Bank and Borrower performances are downgraded to
            unsatisfactory from satisfactory by the ICR and ICR review.
            However, ratings on the National Drainage Project fully
            concur on satisfactory project outcomes, likely
            sustainability, substantial institutional development
            impacts, and satisfactory Bank and Borrower performances.
            Experiences offer two lessons. First, it is reinforced that
            disbursement, and physical achievements are not always good
            indicators of project success, aggravated if failure to
            address systemic institutional problems, adversely affect
            operational efficiency and sustainability of project works,
            making lending ineffective. This not only hampers the
            Bank's reform agenda, but causes also concern among the
            Bank's development partners, who see the Bank as the
            interlocutor capable of advancing institutional, and policy
            reforms with the Government of Egypt. Second, it should be
            taken into consideration the fact that in-country Bank
            partnership with bilateral development agencies, is a
            powerful instrument for institutional reform, who develop
            long-term institution-building relationships with government
            in specific sectors, potentially, and significantly
            increasing the utility, relevance, and leverage of Bank
            assistance. In Egypt, bilateral agencies bring differing
            perspectives to the water, and agriculture sub-sector, and
            are notably strong at capacity building in drainage, and
            community development.

repnme.cdata!:
Egypt - Second Pumping Stations
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            satisfactory. The key lessons learned are: a) A flexible
            program approach has been keen to guaranteeing project
            success, as it allowed the Bank and the implementing agency
            to respond adequately to changes in rehabilitation
            priorities during project implementation. b) The appraisal
            team did not take into account the slow system in Egypt of
            awarding contracts for procurement of goods and the slow
            pace of civil work construction for pumping stations. c)
            Monitoring and evaluation capacity needs to be enhanced at
            Mechanical and Electrical Department (MED) to enable the
            tracking of project costs, benefits, and impacts. d)
            Although not part of the project, it was realized that an
            environment unit is needed at MED to monitor water and other
            related environment quality and alert authorities about
            problems for corrective action. e) In the case of new
            stations, close coordination by MED of the
            electro-mechanical equipment contracts and related civil
            work contracts is key to reducing implementation delays. f)
            There are considerable benefits to having repeater projects
            with the same implementation agency. This allows the
            building of a core professional team at MED that is familiar
            with World Bank requirements for project implementation, and
            that can save effort and time because it is well established
            and operational.

5078932.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!:
Egypt - Second Pumping Stations
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Government has undertaken a
            systematic program to rehabilitate the aging pumping
            stations and upgrade its workshop facilities.  This program
            has been supported by an ongoing project launched in 1983.
            About 70 pumping stations would be rehabilitated by the end
            of 1990.  This project is a continuation of these efforts.
            The main objectives of the project are : a) to avoid future
            declines in yields and agricultural production; b) to reduce
            the operation and maintenance  cost of the pumping stations;
            and c) to strengthen the institutional capability of MED.
            Project components include : 1) rehabilitation of pumping
            stations; 2) supply of workshops, electrical laboratories
            and miscellaneous equipment; 3) civil works ( e.g.
            construction of new pumping stations, workshops, stores,
            offices etc ); 4) institutional support; and 5) technical
            assistance and training.
